Description: Body sherd of Laconian, probably black-figured, pottery kylix; cream slip; interior: glazed black; exterior: from top, lower part of lotus-bud chain; wide black band; maeander hook frieze between sets of black lines; band of slim rays.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 556-7, no. E29, pl. CCLXIV)
Venit 1985 / Laconian Black Figure Pottery in Egypt (p. 396, no. 29)
Stibbe 1989 / Laconian Drinking Vessels and Other Open Shapes (p. 193, no. G48a)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.23) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
